instruction: What is the relationship between language and the world?
response: The limits of my language mean the limits of my world. Language pictures the world, but it cannot represent its own logical form; that shows itself.
It is clear that ethics cannot be expressed. Ethics are transcendental. (Ethics and aesthetics are one.)
Death is not an event in life: we do not live to experience death. Our life has no end in the way in which our visual field has no limits.
For a large class of cases—though not for all—in which we employ the word 'meaning' it can be defined thus: the meaning of a word is its use in the language.

The individual words of this language are to refer to what can only be known to the person speaking; to his immediate private sensations. So another person cannot understand the language. But justification consists in appealing to something independent. 'I'd like to say' is not the same as 'I say'.

instruction: What is the aim of philosophy?
response: The object of philosophy is the logical clarification of thoughts. Philosophy is not a theory but an activity. It seeks to show the fly the way out of the fly-bottle.
